titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Daniel and Hugh Friel letters 1977.425
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-11T15:16-0500

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Daniel and Hugh Friel letters, 1977.425, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Daniel and Hugh Friel immigrated to Brooklyn from Ireland and lived on the corner of Classon and Lafayette Streets. Daniel, the eldest brother, had served in the U.S. Navy on the Frigate Wabash before serving in the Civil War as Second Lieutenant in the 47th New York Volunteers. After the War, he returned to Brooklyn and became a fireman. Hugh also served in the Civil War, enlisting in the 158th New York Volunteers as a drummer boy. He later resided at the Old Soldiers Home in Bath, N.Y., where he died at an advanced age.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection includes letters from Daniel and Hugh Friel to their family, in which they address business affairs, personal matters, and their experiences fighting in the Civil War. The collection includes the original letters along with typed transcriptions. The letters span 1858 to 1866.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mrs. Meyers and Mrs. George Blanchorn, 1965.
